cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 184 (Tuesday, November 7, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. PERRY:H.R. 6276.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8 of the US ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:Directs GSA and OMB to identify utilization rates forpublic buildings.[Page H5545]

item.name: Economic Development, Public Buildings, and Emergency Management Subcommittee

item.title: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 6276) to direct the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to identify the utilization rate of certain public buildings and federally-leased space, and for other purposes, and providing for consideration of the resolution (H. Res. 1065) denouncing the Biden administration's immigration policies.

latestAction.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

item.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Environment and Public Works.
The Clerk was authorized to correct section numbers, punctuation, and cross references, and to make other necessary technical and conforming corrections in the engrossment of H.R. 6276.
The title of the measure was amended. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On passage Passed by recorded vote: 217 - 203 (Roll no. 84).
Passed/agreed to in House: On passage Passed by recorded vote: 217 - 203 (Roll no. 84).
On motion to recommit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 206 - 213 (Roll no. 83).
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mr. Beyer moved to recommit to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. (text: CR H1132)
Considered as unfinished business. (consideration: CR H1131-1133)
Pursuant to clause 1(c) of rule XIX, the House resumed consideration of H.R. 6276.
POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - The Chair announced that pursuant to clause 1(c) of rule XIX, further proceedings on H.R. 6276 are postponed.
The House adopted the amendments en gross as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 6276.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1071, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Rose amendment No. 7.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1071, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the McCormick amendment No. 6.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1071, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the McCormick amendment No. 5.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1071, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Hageman amendment No. 4.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1071, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Hageman amendment No. 3.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1071, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 2.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1071, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Edwards amendment No. 1.
GENERAL DEBATE - The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 6276.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Jennifer A. Kiggans to act as Chairwoman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 1071 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 6276 and H. Res. 1065. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 6276 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit. Resolution provides for consideration of H. Res. 1065 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1071. (consideration: CR H1116-1127; text: CR H1121-1122)

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 1071 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 6276 and H. Res. 1065. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 6276 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit. Resolution provides for consideration of H. Res. 1065 under a closed rule with one hour of general debate.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 314.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. H. Rept. 118-384.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. H. Rept. 118-384.
Ordered to be Reported in the Nature of a Substitute by the Yeas and Nays: 35 - 26.

item.title: H.R 6276, USE IT Act of 2023
item.description: As ordered reported by the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure on December 6, 2023

cdata.text:
Utilizing Space Efficiently and Improving Technologies Act of 2023 or USE IT Act of 2023

This bill requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the General Services Administration (GSA) to establish standard methodologies and identify technologies to measure federal building utilization and to use both to evaluate and consolidate public buildings and federally-leased space. Federal agencies must (1) work with GSA to use sensors and other technologies in public buildings to measure occupancy, and (2) report on actual space utilization.

OMB and GSA must annually ensure building utilization averages at least 60% in each public building and federally-leased space over each 1-year period. The bill also requires OMB and GSA to submit a plan to Congress to consolidate federal agency headquarters buildings in the National Capital region so that building utilization exceeds 60%.

Utilizing Space Efficiently and Improving Technologies Act of 2023 or USE IT Act of 2023

This bill requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the General Services Administration (GSA) to establish standard methodologies and identify technologies to measure federal building utilization and to use both to evaluate and consolidate public buildings and federally leased space. Federal agencies must (1) work with GSA to use sensors and other technologies in public buildings to measure occupancy, and (2) report on actual space utilization.

OMB and GSA must annually ensure building utilization averages at least 60% in each public building and federally leased space over each 1-year period. The bill also requires OMB and GSA to submit a plan to Congress and the Government Accountability Office to consolidate federal agency headquarters buildings in the National Capital region so that building utilization exceeds 60%.

Utilizing Space Efficiently and Improving Technologies Act of 2023 or USE IT Act of 2023

This bill requires the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the General Services Administration (GSA) to establish standard methodologies and identify technologies to measure federal building utilization and to use both to evaluate and consolidate public buildings and federally leased space. Federal agencies must (1) work with GSA to use sensors and other technologies in public buildings to measure occupancy, and (2) report on actual space utilization.

OMB and GSA must annually ensure building utilization averages at least 60% in each public building and federally leased space over each 1-year period. The bill also requires OMB and GSA to submit a plan to Congress and the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to consolidate federal agency headquarters buildings in the National Capital region so that building utilization exceeds 60%.

Occupancy agreements between federal tenants and the GSA shall stipulate annual reporting to GSA on space utilization and occupancy. Federal tenants must return office space to GSA if the occupancy of the tenant falls below a 60% space utilization rate for six months within any 1-year period. Agencies with independent leasing authorities must report space utilization and occupancy annually to Congress.

The GAO shall report on agency costs and occupancy rates for public or federally leased buildings.

Agencies must report certain buildings with utilization rates below 20% to the agency's inspector general for investigation.

item.titleType: Official Titles as Amended by House
item.title: To authorize the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to identify the utilization rate of certain public buildings and federally-leased space, and for other purposes.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 7 printed in House Report 118-419 to require federal agencies to report public buildings or federally-leased spaces with a capacity of 500 or more employees and a utilization rate below 20 percent to their inspector general for investigation.

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Rose amendment (A007) Agreed to by voice vote.

item.text: On agreeing to the Rose amendment (A007) Agreed to by voice vote.
Amendment (A007) offered by Mr. Rose. (consideration: CR H1126-1127; text: CR H1126)
House amendment offered
House Amendment Offered
House amendment agreed to: On agreeing to the Rose amendment (A007) Agreed to by voice vote.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 6 printed in House Report 118-419 to require the Government Accountability Office to report on the cost of conducting the survey and monitoring every federal building's occupancy for a year (including installing sensors in every office of every federal building nationwide).

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the McCormick amendment (A006) Agreed to by voice vote.

item.text: On agreeing to the McCormick amendment (A006) Agreed to by voice vote.
Amendment (A006) offered by Mr. McCormick. (consideration: CR H1125-1126; text: CR H1125)
House amendment offered
House Amendment Offered
House amendment agreed to: On agreeing to the McCormick amendment (A006) Agreed to by voice vote.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 5 printed in House Report 118-419 to require the bill's annual report on the usage of real property be made publicly available on an accessible website run by the General Services Administration with exceptions for national security.

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the McCormick amendment (A005) Agreed to by voice vote.

item.text: On agreeing to the McCormick amendment (A005) Agreed to by voice vote.

House amendment offered

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 4 printed in House Report 118-419 to include employee badge swipe data as a tool for measuring the utilization of public buildings and federally leased spaces.

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Hageman amendment (A004) Agreed to by voice vote.

House amendment offered

House amendment agreed to: On agreeing to the Hageman amendment (A004) Agreed to by voice vote.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 3 printed in House Report 118-419 to require federal agencies to report to Congress on whether occupancy and utilization rates are affected by an agency's remote work and telework policies.

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Hageman amendment (A003) Agreed to by voice vote.

item.text: On agreeing to the Hageman amendment (A003) Agreed to by voice vote.
Amendment (A003) offered by Ms. Hageman. (consideration: CR H1124; text: CR H1124)
House amendment offered
House Amendment Offered
House amendment agreed to: On agreeing to the Hageman amendment (A003) Agreed to by voice vote.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 2 printed in House Report 118-419 to redefine occupancy to include the total number of employees actually performing duties in person in a public building or federally-leased space 40 hours per week.

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Perry amendment (A002) Agreed to by voice vote.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 1 printed in House Report 118-419 to require certain data collection and reporting on space utilization, occupancy, and availability of office space leased by an Executive agency.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
